newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Slow recovery in world steel output - IISI.
newsitem.headline: Slow recovery in world steel output - IISI.

text.p: World crude steel production was 61.3 million tonnes in November, a 2.1 per cent increase on the same month last year, the International Iron and Steel Institute (IISI) said on Wednesday.
But output during the first eight months of the year was 1.1 per cent below the level in the same 1995 period, it added.

Production in the European Union increased 4.3 per cent over November 1995 but the IISI said this could be attributed to "particularly low production levels in the United Kingdom and France in November 1995".
After a sharp drop last month, Italian production recovered slightly to 2.0 million tonnes, but the IISI said this nevertheless represented a 3.6 per cent drop compared with November 1995.
Eastern European production fell slightly to 2.4 million tonnes, 11.4 per cent below November last year. Romania was the only country showing positive growth, up 8.7 per cent from November 1995.
Production in the former USSR dropped 6.4 per cent to 5.9 million tonnes, with Russia suffering the heaviest decline, down 9.7 per cent on last year's November figure.

United States steel production declined 3.5 per cent to 7.5 million tonnes. This proved the exception in North America where "production continues at around last month's levels in Canada and Mexico," the IISI said.

In Asia, November output "showed good growth as the economic situation continues to drive steel demand," the IISI said. Production rose to 23.1 million tonnes, a 4.3 per cent increase compared with the same month last year.
During this period, production in China was up 2.4 per cent while Japaneese production levels rose 6.9 per cent, the highest rise in the region. -- Brussels Newsroom 32 2 287 6800
